As members would be aware, under the Howard government since 1996 the cutbacks that have occurred in labour market programs have had devastating impacts on job clubs throughout Australia and, indeed, on skillshares and other labour market organisations. The Marrickville Job Club has been doing a fine job of assisting unemployed people from all over Sydney to attain skills and access job seeking resources for a period of over 10 years. Marrickville Job Club learnt some three weeks ago that its funding would be cut as a result of the government's new job network initiative. As a result of that, the Marrickville Job Club, which runs out of the May Murray Neighbourhood Centre, was forced to announce its closure. The President of the May Murray Neighbourhood Centre, Mr Michaei Christodoulou, stated: It is the saddest day in the history of our neighbourhood centre. After helping the unemployed for more than 14 years we are now forced to deny our unemployed access to the very tools they need to find a job. This was indeed a very successful organisation. In fact, during the last federal election campaign the then Treasurer Ralph Willis paid a visit to the Marrickville Job Club with me to see first-hand the facilities that these people offered. theText: TodayI want to praise the efforts of the manyThursday, 2 April 1998 MAIN COMMITTEE 2441 and bashings. Such actions not only create social problems in our neighbourhoods, but also add an additional financial strain on individuals and communities. It has been estimated that it costs approximately $45,000 a year to retain a full-time high school chaplain, yet to keep a person in prison costs around $68,000 per year. Simple arithmetic tells one where the social benefits will be. In a recent letter from the Gosnells District Churches Commission on Education, I was advised that the state government's annual grant for chaplaincy support has remained at $90,000 per year for the past six years. I have met several of the non-denominational chaplains who work together with the counsellors and the teachers in high schools. Stuart and Margaret, to mention just two of the young chaplains that I have met, have created a very non-threatening environment which encourages students to discuss their problems. These chaplains have impressed me with their positive approach toward problem solving and their attitude to bridge the emotional gulf that exists between some of the students and their families, friends and the wider community. The chaplains' non-judgmental guidance has helped to bring many students back from the brink of contemplating suicide, homelessness and drug addiction. Yet, because financial support for the important work that the chaplains do comes mainly from personal contributions from the community and local businesses, Stuart and Margaret can only work part time throughout their week. This means that some of the students may reach crisis point without help when they most need it, leading to possible consequences which will be far more costly for governments in a socioeconomic sense. I conclude as I started, by praising the efforts of the people involved in the chaplaincy program. I believe that their guidance and friendship towards the young people whom they support is very necessary in our schools today. This government has already released policies that will tackle youth homelessness, drugs in our community and the unacceptable high level of youth suicide. I urge the government, in further developing such policies, to recognise the valuable work that chaplains can do in our schools. theText: When the coalition government's new bill for theThursday, 2 April 1998 MAIN COMMITTEE 2443 misgivings at the inadequacy of the bill and all the consequent problems and anomalies that will flow. They gave me a detailed breakdown of their concerns and, since the bill was enacted, all their warning signals have in fact eventuated. I received a memo from them only this week that I want to incorporate into the Hansard and I want to ask the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) to address as soon as possible their 13 points of concern. I seek leave to incorporate the memo into Hansard. Leave granted. The document read as followsProblems/Anomalies/Issues re the Superannuation Surcharge (Tax) Legislation Hidden Cost/ Has the Government appreciated the hidden cost of implementing the surcharge legislation, effectively penalising every member of every superannuation fund? ie., the superannuation provider will have to send details of every member each year to the ATO by 31 October? Golden Handshakes If a golden handshake is paid to a taxpayer, then, the taxpayer is liable for the surcharge if his or her adjusted taxable income is greater than the thresho)d. It is said that an assessment for the surcharge will be issued to the member at the time the income tax assessment is issued.' Apart from the funding issues, has the Government considered timing 'anomalies that may arise if the income tax returns are lodged through a tax agent and the lodgement does not take place until the following year and the member is not aware that he or she would be liable for the surcharge? Who is responsible for advising the member? Inequity in Administering Death Benefits Has the Government considered the inequity in relation to the timing and payment of death benefits and the levying of the surcharge? For e.g., where the payment of the contributed amounts or the commencement of a pension is made to a person other than the member (e.g., death benefits paid to a relative) then no surcharge is payable. If, on the death of a member, contributed amounts have not b,een paid before an assessment is issu,ed, then the superannuation provider holding the contributed amounts must pay the surcharge. All in all, this seems some what inequitable. Dividend Imputation Has the Government realised that there is a partial erosion of the benefit flowing from the dividend imputation rules by including the 'gross-up factor' in calculating the taxable income, but not making provision for the franking rebates which are available to reduce income tax otherwise payable? Averaging Provisions-Fluctuating Income Why hasn't the Government made any allowance for those taxpayers who have high income in a certain year because of fluctuating income patterns? Why aren't there any averaging provisions available in the context of the superannuation surcharge? Different Rules Depending on Whether the Amounts are Rolled-Over to a Superannuation Fund or Retainecl Why is the calculation of the surcharge different between ETPs rolled-over and ETPs retained? ie., as the legislation presently stands, where an employee retains such an ETP, it will only be the post20 August 1996 portion of the ETP on which the surcharge will be paid, not the whole post-June 1983 component as is the case where the ETP "is rolled-over. 2444 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 April 1998 What's more, the position changes after 20 August 2001, from which time the whole preand post-June 1983 components (subject to a limited exception) are subject to tax if retained by the employee but only the post-June 1983 component is taxed if rolled-over to a superannuation provider. Late Payment Penalty Whilst the fund is said to be initially liable for any late payment penalty of 20%, has the Government made allowance for tax advisers who may be preparing accounts and tax returns for hundreds of smaller superannuation funds and therefore only have limited time available to comply with the reporting obligations and have genuinely not been able to meet the deadline? Does. the Government intend to surreptitiously shift that burden on to the tax advisers and accountants and also create ill-feeling between advisers and clients? De-minimus Rules Why hasn't the Government incorporated de minimus rules regarding late payment penalties? i.e., interestingly, the legislation does not contain any de minimus rule providing for assessments not to issue where less than some nominal amount (e.g. $20) is payable? Partial Roll-Overs In relation to partial roll-overs, the legislation is silent on the issue of whether a member will have a choice as to which parts of a partial roll-over the surcharge will come from? Variation of Advance Instalment Why is there no provision for variation of advance instalments? No Interest on Refunds Whilst the legislation makes provision for a late payment penalty, why isn't there a corresponding provision for interest on refunds of surcharge, where an advance instalment was paid, but in factÂ· no surcharge liability arose in respect of that member in the following year? Anti-avoidance Legislation Will the Government undertake not to introduce anti-avoidance legislation at a later date and make it retrospective from the date of the commencement of the surcharge legislation? Public Sector Superannuation Funds (Unfunded) Has the Government considered fully the number of anomalies in relation to public sector superannuation schemes? Gold Mining Industry morning-and I assume some people do-will see a letter to the editor from Senator Bob Brown, which is thoroughly dishonest and misleading. Bob Brown says that the government and the Labor Party have sold Aboriginal people out. He says that in fact all that is at stake in native title is the right to negotiate over mining. The senator knows this is simply not true. Should you be seeking a road or a tourist development or a pipeline easement, you are stuck with the right to negotiate. As the former Governor General Bill Hayden said,the right to negotiate in its present form is nothing more than extortion. I think it is about time these green fairies got off the magic mushroom and looked at what actually is happening to Australia. In my own town of Kalgoorlie, things are grinding to a halt as the mines close. These are opportunity mines and usually have a fairly short life. They rely on drilling around them to maintain their ore bodies. That has not happened. When this came in, I warned the Labor Party that the upsurge in drilling that they saw-exploration was on brownfield sites-was in fact being concentrated on there for the very reason of native title. What has happened is that that ground has now been largely explored. They have got the details, development has taken place on that and those mines are running out. In the last three months 15 or 16 mines have closed-none have opened-because there has simply been no exploration on these greenfield areas. The reason there has been no exploration is because of native title-entirely because of native title. People say, 'Oh, there is a downturn in the price.' Yes, there has been a downturn in the price of gold. But in terms of Australian dollars, it is not all that significant. In any case, had we not been held up by native title, these sites would have gone ahead and they would have been developed. They would have been so far down the road that the price of gold would not have stopped them. They would have forward sold their production and they would be in production. In the life of those mines, I would confidently expect the price of gold will turn around and will go up again. (Time expired) Second Reading Debate resumed from 1 April, on motion by Mr Miles:

theText: Anyone reading the Australian newspaper this2446 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 April 1998 That the bill be now read a second time. Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 which contains a number of measures to reform the child support scheme. While these changes will go along way to assist both custodial and noncustodial parents, they only touch the surface of the problems faced by the people involved in the child support scheme. I would like to talk on a couple of these changes that will be implemented by this bill but before I do, I want to relay to the House a situation that occurred recently to one of my constituents, a custodial parent. AlthoughI am often on my feet referring to the inequality or the inequity in the system on behalf of the non-custodial parent, I am just as concerned about the unfairness of the system on custodial parents as well. The matter I wish to raise concerns Mrs CC of Moranbah who had two children by her husband before the marriage broke up. The husband moved away from their home and set up his own. He did not pay child support maintenance because he was an unemployed motor mechanic but he was provided with full access to both children, which is fair enough. After a couple of years on struggle street, the wife approached the husband and asked if he would be prepared to look after the male child while she continued to look after the female child. He agreed. . Shortly after this agreement was reached, the husband decided to move interstate to New South Wales with his son, and nothing was heard of them for five years. Let us be clear: the couple had been living in Moranbah but they split up, and he moved away and has not been paying any child support or any maintenance at all to the custodial parent. She has had to look after both of the children. What has now happened is that, because of the financial burdenand because, I guess, the son may even wish to live with the father-the son has moved away and is now living with the dad. The mum has the daughter, and the dad has the son. Suddenly, out of the blue, the husband applied to the Family Court in New South Wales for access to his daughter, even though he originally had access provided by the Family Court: he had had access but now he wanted greater access. As a result of this, the wife was required to attend the New South Wales Family Court but could not afford to do so because, obviously, she did not have enough finances to be able to travel from central Queensland to New South Wales. However, a family friend kindly provided the necessary funds to allow her to meet the obligations and to take her daughter with her. In the hearing, the father claimed he wanted to see his daughter during summer and winter holidays but that he had no money to travel to Queensland to see her and he requested that the court order the wife to pay half the costs to fly the daughter to New South Wales to visit the father. The judge granted the request, and now the wife has to pay the airfares to send the daughter twice a year to see her father so that he may meet his new access requirements. This is absolutely outrageous. He has never paid maintenance, and now the custodial parent has to actually fly the child to him. It is absolutely crazy. The father has never contributed towards the upkeep of the family since he departed seven years ago and now he expects the mother to pick up half the tab so that he can gain access to the daughter during the school holidays. This is -he problem with the child support system and the Family Court-the whole thing. It is nothing but a shambles. From what we see here, there are basically two ways of looking at child support and the Family Court. There are two fundamental factors. The most

theText: Yes. As I said, we have only touched the edges of this problem. The2448 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 April 1998 bullet our electorate offices will continue to be inundated with complaints from both sides about the scheme's inequity. Raising the non-custodial parent's self-support component by 10 per cent is a nominal gesture but it does not address the inequity that continues to exist. The self-support component for a non-custodial parent is currently $9,006 and it will increase to $9,947. Someone on $42,000 a year would pay about $370 a year in child support. Big deal! The self-support component may be appropriate for someone on basic wages but a lot of my constituents earn higher wages and this amount would not pay their food bill, let alone a mortgage. The self-support component must reflect the non-custodial parent's income and must be increased accordingly. When a family lives together, everyone in that family shares the tax burden imposed on the breadwinner. Yet, when a family breaks up the breadwinner has to meet all the tax burden. This is unfair and I would like to see the self-support component reflect the taxation burden in such a way that it helps reduce the maintenance that some of these high income earners are paying. Additionally, we should look at the custodial parent who reaps the rewards of the noncustodial parent who does overtime or improves his employment status. Many years after the family has broken up, surely any improvements in the status of the non-custodial parent must not result in those benefits going to the custodial parent who is no longer part of the noncustodial parent's family. Basically, the situation is that a person has been in a relationship and the relationship has failed. It is a sad thing but it has happened. We are talking about emotions, we are talking about people's lives. These things do happen. People must have the opportunity to be able to better themselves and move on. If you cannot move on, what is the good of it all? That is the problem we are having with a lot of people out there. I am so passionate about this issue. People are looking at suicide. It is absolutely imperative that we do something about this. That is why if the non-custodial 'parent has the ability to better his life later on, after the family has broken up, then that new income, that new amount of money that he is on whether it is through overtime or a better job, a better salary, should now not reflect on the lifestyle of the previous relationship. Certainly, I hope that can be taken on board. At the same time, I would like to see the self-support component for the custodial parent reduced even more than is proposed by the legislation. At the moment the self-support component for a custodial parent is $39,295 which is based on full-time average weekly earnings, plus an amount for child-care costs for each child under 12 years of age. Removal of the child-care component will reduce the disregarded amount of income for the custodial parent to $30,347. While this is a move in the right direction, it still provides the custodial parent with a disregarded income of over $20,000, which is more than the non-custodial parent self-support. Why is this? The reason given is that the custodial parent must be paid for raising the child or the children. Now, $20,000 equates to about $400 a week so no matter how many children a custodial parent has, they are entitled to an allowance of $400 to raise them, even it equates to one child. For $400, one could leave a child in a child-care centre all week and still have plenty left over. The $400 is still the gross amount above and beyond the actual cost of raising a child. This government has to review further this part of the legislation and bring it into line with . the more acceptable amounts similar to that afforded to the non-custodial parent. For example, Thursday, 2 April 1998 MAIN COMMITTEE 2449 $25,000 is an adequate disregarded amount for a custodial parent to raise a child before they then make some form of contribution themselves. That still provides the custodial parent with $14,000 more in disregarded income than the non-custodial parent, which should be more than sufficient to raise a child. I have heard that the opposition is planning to move some amendments to the government's legislation, which is somewhat hypocritical of them, frankly. The Labor Party had 13 years to do something about the Child Support Agency and the system that it operates under but they ended up doing absolutely nothing. They passed it off to a committee and the committee buried it. The former government's Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues headed by the member for Chifley( Mr Price) started to investigate the problems with the child support scheme. The committee was inundated with 6,800 submissions from all around the country, the most submissions made to any joint select committee, or a standing committee, on any issue investigated by this parliament. That in itself indicated the enormity of the problem. Yet, what did the Labor Party do between the report's findings in 1994 and when they were turfed out of office in 1996? Absolutely nothing. They had the evidence before them; they had the answers before them and they did absolutely nothing. office and they want to get back on the bandwagon. The Labor Party wants to dictate to this government what they want, yet they never had the guts to fix the thing themselves. It is absolutely pathetic. To emphasise the Labor Party's failure, we have the member for Werriwa the legislation that only reflect on this government's actions and not on the child support scheme. He was not much concerned about the inordinate lack of action by his own party which, two years after the report had been handed down, had done nothing to alleviate the concerns of the non-custodial and custodial parents who had made submissions to the committee. found out what the problems were and did absolutely nothing about them. Yet, here they are trying to take the agenda off us and basically trying to run the agenda. It is absolutely hypocritical. As far as I am concerned, his thoughts and his amendments can go where they want; the government will run the agenda on this legislation. The government has done more in two years than the previous government did in 13 and this government will continue to ensure that the child support system becomes a more equitable and more accountable system.

I believe that the new task force which the Prime Minister has announced and which several of us are on will have a great opportunity to address a lot of the problems. valid point that we are picking up a problem that the Labor Party introduced. Yet that party is trying to imply that it is this government that instigated the problem. That is an absolute farce; it is not true. The Labor Party has no clothes and no credibility on this issue. This government, with this task force, will fix the issues and the people who are representative of those lobby groups can rest assured that they have a front door key for dealing with this task force to ensure that their problems are addressed for all the people of this great nation. Marek) that the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 is a small step in the right direction. That is certainly not understating the implications of this bill. The one thing that surprised me when I first came uninitiated into politics as the member for Calare was the overwhelming number of constituents who came to me with family law and child support related problems. It started out as about a quarter of my workload and has not got much below that fraction ever since. Such is the anguish of many people cbping with the child support regime that I was concerned enough to set up a loose network of support in my electorate, where at least people could talk to others in similar circumstances, so emotionally drained were they by not only their family break-up but the frustrations associated with the child support system. By far the major concern has been expressed by non-custodial parents, who find the 18 per cent, 27 per cent, 32, 34 and 36 per cent formulae crippling. The money is determined on gross salary but paid out of net. In one case, I had a former senior education executive with just $25 left-after renting a modest little home-to start a new life, while his former partner not only received the child support but enjoyed the benefits of a very generous property settlement and also the trappings of a very comfortable new relationship. There were five kids aged between 14 and two. I have custodial parents come to me time and time again unable to get anything out of their non-custodial former partners. They know he or she is earning good money but it does not show upiri any declarations or tax returns. Members would no doubt be aware of these sorts of situations. The common thread through it all is the inevitable, clinical way in which these cases are dealt with by the Child Support Agency. I know these people cannot get personally involved in individual cases-quite frankly, theirs must be one of the most depressing, frustrating vocations on offer-but th.ere certainly seems to be a lack of resources to deal with individual cases face to face.

speaker: Mr Andren (Cal Are) (10.16 A.m.)
theText: I note the words of the member for Capricornia ( MrThursday, 2 April 1998 MAIN COMMITIEE 2451 Child support is not social security, it is not about pensions or Austudy, it is not about unemployment-as emotional as those issues can be. The victims are vulnerable, angry, bitter, confused and exasperated. For the non-custodial parent the imposition of the payment formulae on overtime makes no sense at all when he or she is trying to build up a small hank outside their child support commitments to get on with their life or to organise a few treats for those kids when they see them. In this regard I commend the member for Dickson( Mr Tony Smith) for his positive contributions to this debate in the course of this parliament. He has come up with a suggestion, as a barrister experienced in some aspects of family law, for a child support tribunal. I have sought some expert opinion on his suggestion from family law practitioners, and, while there appear to be many areas needing clarification and perhaps modification, he must be congratulated for trying to find a means to overcome the inherent unfairness in the child support system which these government amendments address in some ways, though only very marginally, but certainly do not solve. As we know, the' amendments contained in this bill stem from the 1994 Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, which made something like 164 recommendations for reform of the child support system. The complexity of the changes needed is evidenced by the fact it has taken so long for any meaningful changes to find their way to the parliament by way of these amendments. I welcome the adjusted formula income amounts contained in this bill, but they do not go far enough. . The administrative formula will be modified by increasing the liable parent's exempted income, including an allowance for a shared child, and reducing a carer's disregarded income. However, while welcome, the increase in the paying parent's exempted income by 10 per cent really does not address the problem at all. For a non-custodial parent earning $42,000 a year, the exempted income is increased by about $940 and the child support drops by about $360. That is less than $7 a week, according to my arithmetic. The constituent I mentioned, with the five kids under the age of 14 for whom he is paying a small fortune in child support, has an extra $7 to add to that $25 he now has, after board and reasonable living expenses, to start a new life. The Lone Fathers Association called for at least a 20 per cent increase in the paying parent's exempted income. I understand there are amendments 'coming from the opposition that speak about 15 per cent, out I have not seen them yet. I will look forward to seeing them, as I guess this bill will be referred back to the other place. The 20 per cent that the Lone Fathers Association is suggesting is, to my mind, a very reasonable and meaningful amount. We will have to come back here after several more years, if we do not adjust it now, and adjust this figure to a more sensible one. The problem is that the Institute of Family Studies has determined that it costs $243 a week to keep a teenage child-I think from age 12 or above. That sort of mathematics lies at the heart of the problem with the child support formulae, problems these amendments do not address. There are also concerns that the superficially sensible extension of child support until a child finishes school could lead to manipulation of children on the basis of financial gain and further discriminates against the paying parent who has no say in the current or future dispersal of child support provisions. In fact, figures compiled by the Lone Fathers Association show that the extra payment for children completing school could increase from $1 15,000 to $122,000 over the school life of three children, irrespective of, and despite, these reforms we are speaking about here. 2452 MAIN COMMITtEE Thursday, 2 April 1998 What we really need is to determine the rates of child support on after-tax income to be set at levels that do not wipe out the incentive for non-custodial parents to work. After we take 49 per cent of an income for tax and Medicare levy, 32 per cent for child support for three kids, six percent for compulsory super and 10 per cent costs in earning our income, we are left with three per cent disposable income-hardly fair and not addressed in these amendments. The Lone Fathers Association quite correctly points to another aspect of the bill that seems to address only half the problem. It is proposed that payers with second families will now be able to claim 50 per cent of any child support paid as a deduction for the household used for determining the family's entitlement to family payment and child-care assistance. The association rightly asks: why will payers with second families only be able to claim half of such child support? Surely they should be allowed to claim it all. You are basically making the kids of that next relationship, or the ones that are inherited into that next relationship, pay for the fact that there are kids of another relationship for which child support is due. They should not be punished, and this certainly does not address their concerns. It amounts to a compulsory further payment out of gross income for non-custodial parents in addition to their tax, their child support and their other commitments. The figure does not take into account things like medical or insurance payments and other school or education payments. Really, the non-custodial parent is left high and dry. I notice the cost to the budget of this 50 per cent concession will be about $10 million by the year 2000. It should be $20 million, the whole tab, with the Commonwealth assuming all the costs, because it was unfair as it stood and it is still unfair by a factor of 50 per cent. This bill also makes amendments in the area of parents' rights and responsibilities. There are some useful reforms in this area, particular in enabling parents to move from child support collection to private collection and the limit on the information shown on assessment notices in relation to children of a liable parent. The introduction of child support minimum liability sends the right message to those who would choose to avoid their responsibilities but the minimum of $260 a year is hardly attacking the major problem, which is that many non-custodial parents will continue to take the dole option because of the punitive effects of the formula applied to wages, notwithstanding the changes to the exempted income contained in the bill. Mr Deputy Speaker, I would have liked to have added more to this debate, but time constraints on my research capabilities prevented my doing so. I urge the government to take on board the recommendations from the Lone Fathers Association, particularly in relation to upper limits on child support percentages and the gross versus net income arguments. I agree the child support rate should not exceed 50 per cent of net income after allowing for reasonable deductions to allow the non-custodial parent to get on with a new life. The bill does not address those -issues. It is a great disappointment to me and a source of continued anger and frustration to hundreds of people in my electorate that we are not yet close enough to a fair and equitable child support system. The amendments moved by the member for Dickson are certainly worthy of serious consideration. I have sought some expert opinion on them and I do have difficulty with a tribunal that excludes lawyers, As much as lawyers are not entirely objective, when it comes to talk of excluding them from court or quasi court proceedings such as a tribunal, I accept the advice that I have received that there could be very grave difficulties with the tribunal as envisaged by the member for Dickson's proposal. Thursday, 2 April 1998 MAIN COMMITTEE 2453 I cannot see the two antagonists in a child support dispute sitting down unrepresented in such a tribunal and achieving very much at all. Someone described it to me as the fox chasing the chicken in the pen. The illiterate and those unable to cope with the tribunal atmosphere would also seem to be in a position which would work against any positive outcome. Unfortunately or fortunately, legal representation needs to be available to make the system work fairly but I agree totally with the member for Dickson that we need to consider the particular circumstances of such couples. I have managed to get the Child Support Agency to visit my electorate-as they do now visit most electorates after a lot of pressure from members all across the political spectrum in this area as we came into this parliament. The Child Support Agency did react to the concerns of members. Once about every six months, they talk with the most pressing cases but this only helps about five or six of the 50 or 60 cases I have got on my files at anyone time. While the suggestion of the member for Dickson of a tribunal is a welcome endeavour to quarantine the child support area from the other complexities of the separation and divorce process, I am not convinced it would work and I am not prepared to support his amendments at this point. However, his very thoughtful addressing of this critical issue is to be commended. He shows the need for more compassion and face-to-face treatment of the parties to child support proceedings. There needs to be a far more user-friendly way of handling the appeals process and there needs to be a far more sensible application of the formulae. The member for Capricornia mentioned the government task force. I would suggest, if the government is dead serious about this, that this task force should be non-partisan, non-political and should be extended to include members from all sides of the House. It is a non-political issue; it cannot be politicised. It is a problem that we have all got to address out there. I know every member-I can see it in their eyes here in this place-is confronted with the same number of complaints and concerns that I am in my electorate. We should make it a non-partisan thing if we are serious about what this parliament is all about. I appeal to those members on the government side to take that suggestion to the minister and expand this. I have got enough on my plate but I would certainly like to contribute to whatever deliberations are occurring in this area. I support these government amendments not because they are ideal but because they move reform of child support in the right direction. But it is a glacial movement and these amendments have not been received with any great enthusiasm by either child support parties or the family law specialists whom I have consulted. for cooperating and agreeing to allow me to continue in the debate on the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1998. I do apologise: I was interrupted yesterday by a division in the House of Representatives, and I was tied up with delivering a report in the main chamber as the chair of the Joint Statutory Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund. I have one comment on the suggestion of the honourable member for Calare( Mr Andren) for bipartisan support. I certainly agree that I can see some merit there but I suppose that with some cynicism I have to say that the Price report, from where a lot of these recommendations have come, is not something that has suddenly appeared. It had been around for a long time before we came into government and, prior to our coming into government, much of that report
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Entsch (Leichhardt) (10.30 A.m.)
theText: First of all I would like to thank the opposition2454 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 April 1998 had actually been either left on the table or rejected or not accepted by the previous government. I am not suggesting that members on the other side now have not got commitment; I am sure they have and I would certainly appreciate their bipartisan support In dealing with this very emotional and difficult problem. But we need,. as a government, to go through and identify areas that we feel that we can address immediately. With support from members of the other side and from the Independents, I am confident that we can eventually find a solution. We certainly have the will to do that. Going on from yesterday, the governmentÂ· must address ongoing reforms in the following areas. The formula is one of the problems that most of my constituents agree about: some type of formula is needed to arrive at a reasonable amount payable for child support. However, we all believe more flexibility must be introduced into the assessment process by having a fonnula that not only will enable paying parents to meet their liability but will also firmly establish the role they are playing in the upbringing of their children. The formula as it now stands is based on a certain percentage' of the paying parent's gross or taxable income. This percentage varies, depending on the number of children. Whether the paying parent has one, two or three jobs makes absolutely no difference: they still pay the same percentage of that income. Flexibility must be introduced to allow child support to be calculated on the net income of the principal job only. Capping is another area,' and fixing child support at particular rates is another measure that many payers support. The capped rate would be expected to accurately reflect the genuine cost of maintaining a child or children from the age of one through to 18. Accountability is another problem: a mechanism must be established to ensure that child support payments are actually used for the children and not for maintaining the custodial parent's lifestyle. We must never forget that this scheme is all about child support. Another area is taxation: I feel that rebates on child support payments should be made available to the paying parents. These people pay a high rate of tax, a single rate, while custodial parents are able to claim dependant rebates. There are a lot of other hidden costs, of course, and a mechanism must be established to identify the value of extra expenses that the non-custodial parent incurs in having to provide a suitable home for access visits. Relief could be provided by way of tax relief for mortgage payments or rent. Many parents also incur considerable expense in the provision of air fares for access visits and in the provision of clothing and personal items. These must be identified as legitimate expenses by child support agencies, and relief granted for the paying parent. One of the other problems we have is in regard to self-employed payers. The collection of payments from self-employed payers is a matter of increasing concern in the child support area. One particularly sad case brought to the attention of my office involved a lady who is selfemployed and whose ex-husband manipulated his real income and seriously distorted his capacity to earn a proper income, in order to avoid paying his fair share towards the upbringing of his three children. This resulted in her having to repay almost the total amount of child support he had paid to her over a five-year period. The woman's mother had to sell her own home and purchase a larger house to accommodate her daughter and the three children. If it had not been for that mother, the woman and her children would have been literally living on the streets, whilst her ex-husband received cash Thursday; 2 April 1998 MAIN COMMITTEE 2455 in hand from two companies: he was a silent partner in another company while all the time operating a company of his own and paying almost nothing to his family. I am pleased that we have the child support scheme in place in this country. I sincerely believe that we need it. However, what is of enormous concern to me and many of my constituents is the apparent inconsistencies and inequities in the current system and these must be addressed as a matter of urgency. We need a better scheme, a scheme which focuses on the best interests of the child. Reform of the child support scheme must also include family law and the Family Court. A mechanism must be established to separate family law from child support matters. It must provide fairer access to legal aid; it must address the issue of abuse of access agreements; and it must also address the abuse of domestic violence orders which are being used by lawyers as an interim measure to strengthen the negotiating position of custodial parents. HoweverI will deal with these issues in another place and at another time. I commend this bill to the House. Legislation Amendment Bill 1998. The 148 federal electorates are very different in many respects and the problems and issues put to local members vary immensely, but there is one issue that is prominent in each and every electorate in Australia. That issue is the anger, frustration and disillusionment caused by the child support legislation and, in many cases, the Child Support Agency. At the outset I want to pay tribute to the Child Support Agency office in Wollongong. My office has a very good working relationship with the Wollongong office and because of this relationship we work together to calm some situations and try to resolve the problems that are raised. I note that the honourable member for Gilmore( Mrs Gash) has expressed similar views on the relationship her office has with the Wollongong CSA. In many respects the Child Support Agency offices, spread around Australia, are as much victims of the legislation as are local members, and certainly as much as most of our constituents. The whole area of child support, while so necessary, is for so many people an absolute nightmare. I heard some of what the government members said yesterday. It is all very well to make cheap jibes at the opposition but even government members cannot deny that the original legislation is an example of legislation introduced with the best of intentions to remedy a serious problem but that it has become legislation that has gone horribly wrong. Few people are satisfied with child support legislation. Most people are angry, bitter and very disillusioned. It is a very dangerous cocktail of emotions. Like many members, I can remember the days when women were left partnerless and without financial support to raise children. The unfair burden this placed on these women, because their male partners would not recognise their responsibility for their children, was the primary motive for introducing the child support legislation. I never want to see a return to those days when the custodial parent was left in the financial lurch. But there must be a better way to address the issue of continued support for children from broken relationships. The legislation as it stands today clearly discriminates against the non-custodial parent, be it man or woman, although it just so happens that most non-custodial parents are men.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Hollis (Throsby) (10.36 A.m.)
theText: I wish to speak in this debate on the Child Support2456 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 April 1998 I say this because of the many cases I have dealt with in my electorate. Just as it should be the responsibility of each parent to support his or her children, both emotionally and financially, it should also be the right of each parent to begin and establish, where appropriate, a new relationship. I have dealt with too many cases where the potential to establish a new relationship is flawed because of child support burdens. I have seen the custodial parent, usually a woman, establish a new relationship. Let me be clear, none of us begrudge them this, but in the same circumstances the non-custodial parent, usually the man, because of the financial burden of his child support obligation, is left with not enough to get by on from week to week let alone try to establish a new relationship. Unless you experience this; unless you can see the frustration of non-custodial parents, you cannot appreciate the built up anger they have against this legislation. It is very rare for me to hear any non-custodial parent tell me that they do not recognise or accept their responsibility to support their children. The vast majority of non-custodial parents are responsible and supportive of the children, but they are being treated unfairly by the legislation. I like to pride myself on being a good local member, as we all do, dealing with the problems of my constituents and hopefully having some success. Yet, on child support issues, the dominant feeling in my office, and I suspect the offices of each of us, is utter hopelessness. I know that each of us can present various cases and I want to outline a couple now. Take for example the case I have seen recently of a woman with two children. She is not yet divorced but has had the property settlement. She had to pay the husband $75,000 to get the house. She took out a mortgage on the understanding that the husband would pay child support. She is on a single parent pension, and this is a little like the example given by the member for Leichhardt ( Mr Entsch). The husband left his job and purchased a business as a silent partner. He has had all his assets transferred out of his name and he has said that he will never pay child support. The woman has had to seek financial assistance from her parents but her husband is getting away with it because the CSA enforcement team is taking such a long time to investigate the matter. Another case involves a man who must pay $850 per fortnight for three children. He sold some shares and received $28,000. He used the money to pay off the mortgage, which benefited his former wife because she has the home. The CSA have added the proceeds to his annual income. Instead of bdng assessed at $50,000 a year, they added the $28,000 that he got for selling the shares and he has now been assessed at $78,000. This man's average fortnightly net pay is $1,197, less child support, superannuation and private medical insurance and he is left to live on only $167 per fortnight. This man cannot afford to rent, to live or to pay for his car. He lives with his parents. I ask: what chance does he have of establishing a new relationship? I would like to talk about how some of these cases are assessed. A man came to see me once as he was having difficulty with the payment. He had two children and he was paying child support for them. As so often happens, he was quite bitter about the relationship. On an occasion that the children came to visit him, he thought that, considering the amount he money he was paying each fortnight, their clothes were not appropriate-they were torn and so forthso he formally complained about that. The agency then said that as he had complained about it he obviously was not paying enough for the woman to adequately clothe the children so they hit him with a bill for a 'couple of hundred bucks and added $20 a fortnight to what he was paying. Thursday, 2 April 1998 MAIN COMMITTEE 2457 I know that I could go to every member of parliament and they could all tell me of these sorts of examples. The cases are just unbelievable. I know that many men feel that it is discriminatory against males. When I said I was going to put that in my speech one of my staffers said that I should not because, as they said, the system discriminates against the noncustodial parent rather than the male; it just so happens that many of the cases we see in our offices are men. The tragedy of relationship breakdown is the raw intensity of the bitterness involved. We always think that we are mature enough to handle the emotional aspect of a breakdown in a sophisticated manner but, more likely than not, this never happens. I have enormous sympathy for the innocent parties in a relationship breakdown-the children and the other family members. Grandparents are one such group of innocent people. They are in an impossible position because it is either their son or their daughter that is involved. They are caught in the middle of a raw emotional battle. This has happened in my own family. I know of cases where grandparents are not permitted to see their grandchildren-they are lost in the hostile bitterness between son and daughter-in-law or daughter and son-in-law in the ending of the relationship. Often the grandparents are quite friendly or quite sympathetic to the two warring parties but then they become victims when they are denied access to the grandchildren. There have been cases recently where, in a way, that is now being remedied. But they can get caught up in a legal situation-in an incredible, immensely emotional battle. I do not profess to have all the answers but there are some issues the legislation must recognise, including the formula used to assess contributions. We all say that the amount under the formula is too high, but it has never been addressed. Child support assesses a person's gross income, not their net. Nobody receives a gross income and it should not be used in any assessment. Most non-custodial parents are forced to work overtime to make up the shortfall in their pay at the end of each fortnight. But this increases their assessable income and for so many people it is a catch-22 situation. What is the point of working overtime when your payments are going up all the time? People come and say to me all the time, 'I would be better off just going away somewhere on the dole'. That is happening time and time again. In my view, direct payments made by non-custodial parents to assist in raising their children, such as payments of boarding fees, health fund fees and tuition fees, should all be assessed as part of the child support payment, not in addition to it. Nobody can get blood out of a stone, nor should non-custodial parents be relentlessly squeezed. While the opposition does not oppose this legislation, we do believe a number of amendmentneed to be made. I support what the government is doing. At least it is a move, but it is a very tiny move. This legislation is not going to solve the problems. It is not going to stop the anger, the frustration and the disillusionment out there. It is a move but a very slow move. I agree with what the honourable member for Calare( Mr Andren) said. WhatI would really like to see-I know it is impossible but I would really like to see it-is the removal of party politics from this debate. I would like to see a solution based on some consensus which is fair to both of the parents of the children and, most importantly, to the children themselves. I believe honestly that each of us should be allowed a free vote on this issue. In this way and only this way will we begin to address this problem. It is a problem that we all have in our electorates and we must do something about it. I believe that, for once, on this issue-as 2458 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 April 1998 on the abortion issue, as on the euthanasia issue, where we found on both sides of politics that we took different points of view; I do not think that on this issue we would, and the divide will not be so great-we should be permitted a free vote. It is not so much about a vote on this legislation. What we have got to do is just to get together sensibly and cut out the party politics, because we are dealing with human lives, we are dealing with kids' lives, we are dealing with emotions. What we have got to do is to sit down as mature adults, come up with some workable solution to what is a problem out there in the community and then cut the party politics out of it, bring it in to this place and pass it on a bipartisan basis. That may be unrealistic or an idealistic dream, but it is the sort of thing we are going to have to do. What really frightens me is that out there in the community there is so much frustration. There is so much bitterness in the people who are coming to my office that I just think, 'What can I do?' When I have not been able to solve their problem they go out of the office with this bitterness built up inside them. UnlessÂ· we address the problem urgently we will have created a generation of bitter, frustrated parents at each others' throats, using their children as pawns in an emotional game. More important, we will have created a generation of bewildered children continually tom between conflicting loyalties. For God's sake let us all get together and do something about this monstrous problem out there in the community. Throsby( Mr Hollis) are very wise words. I believe that in many respects party politics have to be taken out of this. Goodwill, I believe, does exist on both sides of the House. I believe that there needs to be a thorough discussion in the House and a free vote in relation to the matter. We certainly need to get together on it. The issue of child support has received considerable airing in this parliament since I have been here. In fact, I think that it is probably the most talked about issue next to tax. The fact is that the child support system has been under considerable criticism for all of that time. Much of the criticism is, in my view, quite justified because of the division that the activities of the Child Support Agency cause, and the surrounding circumstances involving family law. These things lead to division. These things tear people apart. These things tear people's lives apart. I will make some brief preliminary comments on what has been said already. The member for Chifley( Mr Price) made some comments about the need for a fresh approach. I thoroughly respect the member for Chifley. He Was involved in the previous government's committee on the matter and said some wise words. I am concerned about his comments in relation to the bill-I have not been able to check these comments out-which suggest that the effect of the bill is that there is going to be somewhere between $47 million and $26 million more going into consolidated revenue. I do not know whether that is correct, but I would be concerned if it were. The member for Calare( Mr Andren) made some comments in relation to the tribunal question. I am going to go into that shortly, but let me just tum now to briefly enunciate on a couple of matters that I think have to be addressed by way of preamble. When a marriage has broken down, one thing is absolutely certain: nothing can ever be the same again. The lifestyle that the couple once had together as a couple has henceforth ceased. It does not lie in the mouth of any party to that relationship to say that the lifestyle has to be maintained.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Tony Smith (Dickson) (10.49 A.m.)
theText: The words of the honourable member forThursday, 2 April 1998 MAIN COMMITTEE 2459 It cannot be. It can never be. There is a philosophy, in my view, that has insinuated its way into the child support act, such that it is a lifestyle thing. What people are saying in this debate, and what people are saying about child support, is that it is unfair. If it is not child support, it is unfair. It is about child support and not lifestyle. But there is no doubt at all that this particular act is about lifestyle. Unfortunately, these amendments do not address the key element, and that is whether we are able to make child support really child support. I believe that the golden principle of maintenance of children is that it is the responsibility of parents capable of supporting the needs of the child, or the children. That principle of maintenance, as I say, has been abrogated. That is not to say that the Child Support Agency has not effected some good work in relation to gathering in its net people who did not adhere to orders. But prior to 1989, orders for maintenance were made by the Family Court and the Magistrate's Court and the system worked reasonably well. The problem was in the collection. With the advent of the sole parent pension introduced in the 1970s, unscrupulous use was made of the Australian taxpayer to fund children's maintenance, and parents avoided their obligations to their children. This situation had to be addressed-there is no doubt about that. But, really, instead of rejigging the enforcement structure that already existed in the Magistrate's Court and the Family Court, we have gone to this overarching and overreaching monolith called the Child Support Agency. There is no area of the public service that is growing at a faster rate than the area of the Child Support Agency. It has produced more heartache, more conflict, severed more families, driven more people to suicide, provoked more people to despair, alienated more children from their parents, and provoked more anguish amongst grandparents, than any other area of public service. There are some little-known statistics. I am not one who blindly accepts statistics, but in the course of thinking about this particular matter, I said to one of my staff who had been married for more than 20 years to the one person-and neither of them had been married before-'I believe that you are in a significant minority amongst Australian people. Let us look into it and find out what the statistics are.' I found out that there are fewer than 10 percent of Australian families regarded as traditional. That means that the child support system touches a great mass of people across the country, but this is not realised by the government. It is not sufficiently realised by us all that it touches this great mass of people-grandparents, great-grandparents in some cases. All these people are caught up in this terrible net and the terrible anguish. The statement that we have to look after Australian families does not wash too well with the people who are caught up in this system, which is the vast, overwhelming majority of people. We have to realise that for a start. In devising policies, we have to realise that and to appreciate that that is the case. The bill before the House, while providing some relief, does not go to the heart of the problem. As I said, that is unfairness. Of the many hundreds, if not thousands, of people I have spok-n to about this issue since becoming the member for Dickson, let me tell you about one of the most moving cases I had just recently. A deputy principal of a high school came to see me. He had 20 years experience as a counsellor, a relatively lengthy marriage and three teenage children. You could not find a more loving and caring father. Now he is living in a small flat. The property settlement gave him $15,000 but gave his wife $125,000. He had put $18,000 from his father's estate into their 2460 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 April 1998 home three years before, and he got $15,000 back-less than what was put in from the estate. He did not even get that back. Apart from the incredible depression of having lost his position as a father and mentor to his children-and nothing is ever the same once you lose that bond-he has to contend with the ravages of the agency. Out of approximately $58,000 a year, he is left with about $250 a week on which to live and to provide entertainment and some sort of lifestyle for the three teenage children. He told me his story and a portion of the conversation was almost indescribable. When I asked him, 'What are you going to do?' he stopped and he could not talk. He physically could not talk-he tried to but he could not move. He was trying to speak, and before my very own eyes he aged 10 years. It was incredible. There were tears in my eyes when I saw it, and afterwards I needed half an hour before the next appointment to get over what this man had gone through. I said, 'I want the Prime Minister and the Minister for Social Security to be here to see you, because they do not understand what is happening.' This is what is happening and we are seeing it. We are saying this but we are not getting listened to, I am afraid. office of the member for Throsby probably gets more than some-do not get it as much as others, but we all get some of it. Finally, the man said to me, 'AllI can do is give up being a principal and go back to supply teaching,' because he could not stand it any more. What a loss that is. Let me tell you about one other case. This fellow had worked for the Victorian transport commission for seven years before he was married. He had a seven-year marriage, and there were three children. At the end of that marriage, his wife left and went to Queensland. He tried to see his children. He had had a property settlement, and he had lost his house and his car-it was a house he had before he was married, by the way. He had all of these things taken away, and he finally had to say to his employer, 'I will have to take a redundancy. I cannot afford going backwards and forwards from Victoria to Queensland to see my children.' He came to Queensland, where he has a $2,000 bomb car and is living in a very modest rented home in Keperra in my electorate. The Child Support Agency said, 'Hey, you got a redundancy and it was X amount of dollars. We are going to hit you for 30 per cent of all of the redundancy' -the redundancy from before he was even married. I said to a senior member of the Child Support Agency, 'This is absolute theft. This money belonged to him from before he was married.' Unfortunately, that is an anomaly in the system. How can we possibly stand here in this HQuse and say, 'We have made a few adjustments to it,' when that situation is not addressed. In that particular case, his wife is living in a lovely home, she has a $30,000 car and, he added, 'For good measure, she's had her boobs done.' That is the sort of situation, funny as it sounds, that is absolutely tragic. It is lifestyle and we need to do something about it. (Time expired) Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1998. The bill implements the package announced by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) in September last year. It is the second stage of the government's reforms and it builds on the changes made last year to the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989. The 1994 Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues made 163 recommendations, and the chairman of that committee is with us in the Main Committee today. The interim response of the government to that report canvassed 53 of those recommendations and, last year, amendments addressed a further 11. The legislation before us brings the total addressed to 111. This package is based on the principle of parental responsibility, with a preference for private arrangements and with the government acting as a safety net for those unable to access such arrangements. The details of the bill are basically to do with enhancing the parents' capacity to provide financial support. Payers of child support will have more of their income exempted from the CSS formula, and the disregarded income level for carers will be reduced. To tackle the apparent evasion of child support, rental property losses and previously exempt foreign income will be included in the assessable income of non-custodial parents. Furthermore, the registrar of the CSA will be given powers to better assess the declared financial circumstances of par<?nts, in order to ensure calculation in as fair a way as possible. In order to make payments more flexible and to ensure fair and reasonable calculations, certain care arrangements will be taken into account in the calculation process. In terms of parents' rights and responsibilities, the bill provides a number of additional rights and responsibilities for parents, both custodial and non-custodial. Some of these changes include allowing either parent to apply for administrative assessment of child support; and allowing the registrar to suspend payments of child support where the Family Court has been asked to make a decision. Private collection will be encouraged. Child support may continue until the end of the school year or until a child who is still a full-time student turns 18. The bill also includes measures placing a greater onus on parents to notify changes in their circumstances to the CSA. There has been great criticism of the CSA and CSS, criticism which I am sure every member and every senator would be aware of, as there is an unwieldy bureaucracy involved in its operation. This bill will remove retrospectivity in relation to the commencement of a liability; it will enhance payment options for liable parents; and it will allow the registrar to offset debts between parents. That is the basis of the legislation, as we all know. I will now make a few personal observations for five or six minutes and I look forward to enjoying the contribution from my colleague from Western Australia, the honourable member for Stirling( Mr Eoin Cameron). The Child Support Agency is an offshoot of the Australian Taxation Office, as we know. It has about 2,500 employees, public servants, costing the taxpayer in excess of $125 million per year, I understand. It has been attempting, over the past decade, to deal with a very deeprooted community change to do with the changing stability, if you like, of life contracts in marriage or in relationships. Parents are changing their circumstances and therefore the support arrangements for the children of those relationships are becoming increasingly complex in some cases. speaker: Mr Wakelin (Grey) (11.09 A.m.)
theText: We all understand the background to the Child2464 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 April 1998 as I understand it, the increasing social welfare bill: parents who had conceived children would accept the maximum possible responsibility for their care, according to their means. But, as ever when the government gets involved in matters of human activity, it is less than perfect. From my experience in my electorate office, I do not think there is an issue which evokes more emotion, difficulty and frustration than this one does. It is a blight on our society that we have not been able to be more successful. I do not blame anyone for that: the previous government made some genuine attempts, and this government has made some genuine attempts, but we have not addressed the issue at anywhere the level that we need to in order to bring about a reasonable acceptance of parental responsibility and the proper balance of the law. I will give you a couple of examples and as I talk about them. I will think of another 10 and so maybe I will pick out another one. This particular example will stay with me forever. I had a chap come into the office, a man in full-time employment, and he told me his story. His daughter had brought a child support scheme action against him, her own father, for the care of her younger sister, his younger daughter. I checked with the minister's office. I could not believe it; I did not think that would be possible. However, after checking with the minister's office, I found that it was true. He told me his story with great dignity and great strength. He told me of his comment to his 19-year-old son when his son endeavoured to understand this: 'We're not worth as much, mate, because you're over the age of 18.' That explained to me the complex nature and the difficult nature of the legislation that we have got ourselves involved in. I have found the issue of the Australian Taxation Office to be less than satisfactory. In these matters where people are in the most difficult circumstances they will ever confront in their lives, a relationship breakdown, we need an organisation with a little more care and a little more compassion. I do not believe the Australian Taxation Office is where this organisation should be. In the two or three minutes I have remaining I want to raise three matters where I think the cause may be advanced, because I do not want to see these amendments as the final chapter in this thing. I do not think they can be. I think we have at least two more stages to go over the next year or two to bring it to some reasonable conclusion. Like all speakers on both sides of this debate, I want to enable people to have some kind of a new life once a relationship breaks down, and the focus of all that is reasonable care for the children. I will offer three points. Firstly, I believe the parliament must look at proper incentives for private arrangements. If we bring children into the world then we have a responsibility to care for them. I guess we have that responsibility to the day we die, but certainly until the child's legal age of 18. Whatever our personal relationships might be with the other parent, we must always respect that. That is the principle we have to bring from the parliament to the people on this issue. We have to bring it home to people who have children that they have that responsibility to make sure they care for their child to the best of their ability. The government has to offer the proper balance and incentives to make sure that they can do that. The government has to ensure that there are incentives for private arrangements for payments to be made for the care of a child when a relationship breaks down. I mention again the 2,500 public servants, the $150 million of taxpayers' money, just to say that parent A should pay parent B. Surely it is better for parent A and parent B, as difficult as that might be, to come to their own arrangements. Hundreds of thousands of Australians Thursday, 2 April 1998 MAIN COMMITTEE 2465 do that. Therefore, we want incentives for those other hundreds of thousands of Australians who cannot do that to be brought into that net as much as possible. The second point I wish to stress is the imbalance in the equity between the custodial and the non-custodial parent. Many speakers have spoken of that. We cannot have this imbalance between the custodial and the non-custodial parent. We must move to complete fairness. It has to be gender neutral. It is not a matter of female or male. It is a matter of the overall responsibility and fairness. We have to ensure that people can begin their lives and give maximum care to their children. The last point I will make is that it must come back to a reasonable philosophical base. It must come back to what I talked about earlier, about respecting the fact that parents do have that fundamental responsibility. In regard to the responsibility of MPs, I guess that will be never ending and I believe it is totally unsatisfactory -nder our current structure. One particular issue that I would wish to bring to the public mind is that, in regional Australia, it is significantly difficult because the Child Support Agency does not have offices readily available around Australia and, therefore, access to the offices of that organisation is somewhat more difficult. That is just another issue that regional Australia has to contend with. There are a couple of other smaller points. I believe we have the technological ability now to reflect the fortnightly wage, and if we must stick with this gross wage formula we do have the ability not to go on some historical 12-month basis. With computers these days, there should be no trouble reflecting the actual wage of that fortnight. It should not be difficult to do that. These historical arrangements are just so unfair. They only further provoke people and lose greater credibility for our system. I do not wish to go any further. I am sure many other speakers have canvassed the range of issues on this matter. It is terribly difficult, but we have to keep trying. We are a number of years away from the proper answer on this matter. The overwhelming thing that I would like to leave with the Main Committee is that we must allow people to get on with a new life and to give those children the best chance. theText: I welcome the introduction of this Child2466 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 April 1998 were due to board the plane in the eastern states to fly to Perth, his wife would call and say, 'So and so has got a cold and cannot fly.' This would mean that he had to rebook. The child, of course, would have a miraculous recovery the next day. He would have to rebook and pay the full fair. It was j!lst sheer spite. Stories like that are legend. I think so many of my colleagues can tell stories like that. The fact that the wife had remarried and was a millionaire was beside the point. She was just meting out all kinds of vicious treatment when she could. When Benjamin Franklin said the two certain things in life were death and taxes, he obviously did not foresee the Child Support Agency and the associated problems there. Unfortunately, we will never have adequate legislation in the eyes of those affected by the child support act. Either way, one party will always be in dispute with the other and I do not have enough feet and hands to count the number of allegations that have come into my office of former partners evading tax, hiding income, ripping off Social Security and t-e like. Nevertheless, while this act will never be amended to the satisfaction of everyone, it can be improved, and I am confident that the changes proposed to this legislation do go some of the way towards fixing the child support act. The important principle highlighted by this bill is that the parents hold primary responsibility for the financial support of their children, and it is high time all parents adhered to this principle. Children come into this world, more often than not, from a loving partnership. Too often, that partnership dissolves and too many parents do their utmost to avoid contributing to the upbringing of their children. In the House the other day I spoke about domestic violence and mentioned that children learned from their parents. It is such a shame that many children learn these days that it is easy to divorce, that it is worthwhile fighting over evading responsibility for the upkeep of dependants. One aspect of this legislation I particularly support is that the minimum child support liability for all payers should be $5 per week, including for those receiving income support. I wholeheartedly agree with that particular policy for it is a sign to parents that they cannot evade their responsibilities altogether. It reinforces the principle that parents should share in the cost of supporting their children, and there is nothing wrong with the notion that parents accept responsibility for their children. I do get extremely cheesed off when people threaten to quit their job and go. on the dole so that they do not have to carry out the responsibility of providing for the upkeep of their offspring. By taking a token sum from the social security payments of parents, it reinforces the principle that both parents are responsible for the upkeep of their children, irrespective of their source of income. A further pleasing aspect of this legislation is that it allows parents to move, by agreement, from Child Support Agency collection to private collection. I have had parents come and see me seeking this option. If parents can take on that responsibility, they should be allowed to do so. Furthermore, the registrar can also require parents to move to private collection if it is considered that regular payments will continue-and that, indeed, is a welcome sign. The less government intrusion into the lives of Australians the better. The Child Support Agency will still provide parents with a service to determine the amount payable and to register parents' agreements and court orders. The bill also recognises the difficulties for some paying parents in maintaining their own life, notwithstanding the responsibility to their children. Paying parents still have a right to a reasonably normal life, and to have another relationship and family if they so choose. This legislation makes amendments to better recognise the capacity of parents to pay, which is, of Thursday, 2 April 1998 MAIN COMMITTEE 2467 course, a source of numerous complaints to my office and, I am sure, the offices of my colleagues. I am pleased to support the legislation. It meets with the satisfaction of a number of my constituents who have contacted me since the changes were announced-in fact, they were delighted with the proposals. I must say this is not the end of the government's changes to child support. I welcome the fact that a task force of government members will be established to examine further proposed changes to the child support scheme. theText: Thank you very much.
